Posts.Content: May 19, 2013 05:55AM - edited May 19, 2013 05:58AM by barsco1963 suecolo2 - nausea is sometimes difficult to deal with. I have been dealing with it for well over a year now. I have tried a few anit-nausea meds. Some didn't work for me and some did for a while only to give way once more to the nausea. I too have lost a lot of weight but am now trying another med that is doing ok. Not a complete reprieve but it does help. It might be worth it to talk it over with your dr to see if there is another med which you could try. I also drink a lot of ginger tea and that seems to settle things quite a bit. I just peel and cut up a small bit of ginger root and add it to boiling water.  I sure hope you find something to help you out. (edited) Just a note to say that I am still on tamoxifen which is what I believe is causing my nausea. However, not willing to give up the tamo as it is doing wonders at keeping me stable.

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2013 12:14PM barsco1963 wrote: survivor - I also have experienced a weight loss and nausea which I didn't seem to have any reason for. I was pretty sure from the beginning that it was the tamo that was causing nausea. However, onc would not agree with me until lately after testing for everything else under the sun. I tried various anti nausea drugs to no avail. I am now on an anti depressant along with an anti nausea which seem to be helping. The nausea is not as prominent as it was. Still having some digestive issues but things are much better. I didn't think that it was a psychological issue but, am now wondering about that. I was at one point afraid to eat anything with sugar, or dairy or soy and wasn't sure what I could eat....so I ate little. Once I realized that I needed to get nutrition of some sort into me, I found that smoothies went down easily - just mixed a bit of greek yogurt for protein, some milk, and fruit/fruit juice. Also soups, oatmeal & ice cream/frozen yogurt, rice, pasta. Nutritionist advised to stay away from the Ensure and Boost shakes due to the soy content. There is a Boost fruit drink that she suggested. Take it one day at a time and try not to think about your weight, but rather about eating healthy so that your body has the energy to deal with whatever comes along. Good luck - let us know how you are making out.

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2013 06:13AM barsco1963 wrote: I am a positive person by nature and that is one thing that cancer has not taken from me and I hope that it never does. However, I do have days when I think about the down side of everything - it is scary and we all have every right to feel sad, depressed, and angry at times. Just like everyone else in the world. Some people just never "get it". One coworker insisted on telling me that I "looked to good to have cancer" on more than one occasion. I finallly told her that the ugly was "all on the inside". She has asked more than once how long tx will be. And the topper? At a friend's b-day party the conversation came around to bc and after some discussion, she said "You're not going to die." I should have asked her to put that in writing but I didn't want to ruin the party mood so I just smiled and moved on. Cancer does not give anyone reason to be happy, grateful, or blessed. It is not a gift. But we do have to remember that we are more than just a "cancer patient" There are other things in our lives that we can be thankful for. And that is what I try to concentrate on. BB - I hope that the Xeloda is what it takes to knock back the progression and that Reggie has just stepped out for a short walk. Wishing you brighter days ahead. ((hugs))

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2011 09:29AM barsco1963 wrote: I am a 47 yr old whose original diagnosis (2011) was bc with liver mets. I have learned a lot through the web especially www.mbcn.org and www.metavivor.org both sites are great references. Metastatic breast cancer is scary but it is important to stay positive and strong. Be your own advocate and don't be afraid to ask questions. I don't think anyone can tell you life expectancy. I do know that there are women with metstatic bc that have lived for 15 yrs or more. My treatment is different than I had expected (chemo, then radiation). I am taking Tamoxifen daily and a monthly injection of Zoladex. Every diagnosis and treatment are very personalized. I hope that you continue to check in here for support and to hear of the experiences of others.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2013 08:38AM barsco1963 wrote: Papillon - Have been lurking here a bit and just want to say that I sure hope the new meds help out with your mom's nausea. It is a horrible thing to deal with on a daily basis. Chrissy's idea of smoothies are a great idea, you can add protein powder, spinach, kale, etc. There are also meal supplement/replacements available here, but not sure if you have them where you are. Boost, Ensure, and Glucerna are some of the ones I know of. The boost comes in a smoothie type as well as a juice type. I have also been dealing with nausea for a long while and although not much fun - forcing ones self to eat is sometime necessary (as long as it doesn't cause vomiting). Other options might be - soda crackers, dry cheerios, rice, mashed potatoes, or anything bland tasting. It is sometimes the smell of food that causes one to become nauseated and not want to eat. Try to encourage her to continue eating and drinking throughout the day. Please keep us posted on how your mom is doing.

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 10:23PM barsco1963 wrote: Hi sgupta - sorry that you have been dx with mets. You have come to the right place for support and encouragement. I was dx with liver mets from the start. I too was started on tamoxifen and a month later started to receive zoladex injections which I now get every 3 months. I was concerned about not getting chemo - I thought everyone had to do chemo. But after discussing with my onc, he stated that we were going to start with hormonals and keep the big guns (chemo) for later on down the road. The hormonals are working very well for me - tumors continue to shrink since last year. Speak with your onc for a clearer understanding. Get a second opinion if you are still unsure or uncomfortable with the decision. Good luck - keep us posted!

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2013 08:49PM barsco1963 wrote: papillon - sorry to hear that the lesion on your mum's liver has increased in size. I hope that this new chemo will knock it back for her. Moonflwr - I can't help you out with your question on tx. I only know that tx for stage iv is more about QOL rather than obliterating the beast. Not everyone wants to know the "what ifs" or all of the possible SEs of their tx. I encourage you to make sure that your SIL would not be put out if you were to research her tx. However, you can still be a great support for your SIL without knowing all about the tx that she is on. Encourage her to rest if you see that she is pushing too hard, if you think a SE warrants a call to the onc then help her to make the call. As you know, what may be common SEs for one, may be totally different for another.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2013 07:15AM barsco1963 wrote: karody - sorry that you are not feeling well. It was not you that didn't handle the chemo well, it was the chemo that was very rough on you and your body. It is hard not to think of mets every time there is an ache or pain. Often the meds we are given have SEs which cause a lot of aches/pains. I have been told that if the symptom/pain lasts for two weeks or more then it should be checked out. I have just gone through a yr where I was sure that everything was a symptom of progression or new mets. Definitely worrisome. But after all of the scans and testing and now with the help of Ciprilex, I am feeling a bit more relaxed about things. It all takes time and perhaps some anti anxiety drugs to help us enjoy more of the good and push the fears to the back burner. I hope that you are able to get to a place where you are feeling better both physically and emotionally. ((hugs))

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 02:37PM barsco1963 wrote: Hi - I am 48 and was diagnosed last yr at 47 yrs old. I cannot believe how naive I was before dx - I have learned so much in the past 8 months. While looking through some reading material that was sent home from hospital with me - I found bc.org and checked it out. About a week after umx a CT scan showed spots on my liver. I was devastated. But a US guided biopsy noted that it was not cancer. Hooray!! But - wait a minute - the doctor also noted that he could not be sure he got a good sample as the US was not very clear and it was hard to see. So a second CT guided biopsy was ordered and confirmed mets. :( On one hand I was glad that I would not have to do chemo & rads (not now at least), but on the other hand...........mets. I am still at odds with how to deal with it - most days are good. I have an "it is what it is" attitude. The tx is working very well  (tamo & zoladex) as tumors continue to shrink. So I concentrate on that and try to appreciate each day that I am given. I have a wonderful support network of family and friends, which I am truly thankful for. There is so much inspiration and support here. I don't post a lot, but do read a lot of threads and try to post words of encouragement and support when I can. I look forward to being here for a long, long time. Barb

Posts.Content: barsco1963 wrote: It's been 2 years since dx of stage iv bc. After reading all of the horrible stats etc regarding liver mets, I never thought that I would be here and doing well at this point in time. Then I found BCO and all of the wonderful persons here that have been such a great source of support, friendship, encouragement, love, laughter, hope and reality. Sadly there have been many sisters who have passed since my joining here. I only hope that they know how much their words and support have helped others here to move past the fear and enjoy the here and now. I am very grateful that I have responded so well to first tx. I am living a decent QOL and have returned to working full time (jury still out on that being a good thing - lol). I pray daily for all who are dealing with this horrible disease in any way and at every stage and thank those who take part in trials in order to find more and better tx. Thanks to BCO for providing a place for us all to come and share our fears, experiences, and to connect with others who "get it"  Bless us all! Barb It isn't knowing the worst, the worst is not knowing. Dx 5/30/2011, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 21/29 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 7/24/2011 Log in to post a reply
